name: International Association for the Catalytic Control of Ship Emissions to Air
goal:
The primary purpose our organisation is to demonstrate the technological and economic viability of utilizing after treatment technology to reduce emissions from ship engines.

Through this brief we have developed a reputation as thought leaders on marine emissions, not just NOx but also SOx and PM (specifically becoming a leading authority on all the major technologies which are considered capable of meeting IMO Tier III emission limits.).

We have contributed to the impact assessments for the Baltic and North Sea/English Channel ECAs and we play a key role at the IMO, specifically as part of the NOx Review Correspondence Group.

IACCSEA aims to use its voice to demonstrate to regulators and the shipping sector that tough limits can be met through commercially available after-treatment technology.

The overarching objectives of the Association as described in the IACCSEA Charter and Constitution are:
 Promote the technological and economic viability of using catalytic emission control technologies on ships;
 Demonstrate to regulators and the shipping sector that proposed regulations, for example IMO Tier III, can be met through commercially available catalytic after-treatment;
 Engage the IMO, EU, US EPA and other regulatory organisations in relation to the formation and implementation of ECA’s, and the development of certification schemes;
 Engage and coordinate activity with like minded industry associations and NGOs with an interest in similar policy outcomes;
 Gather and disseminate objective and factual technical information on marine catalytic emission control technologies (including costs, benefits and competing technologies);
 Develop key messages and publish them through an Association website, trade journals, conferences and seminars
euInitiatives: IACCSEA have an interest in the incorporation of marine pollution into the European Air Quality agenda. Specifically we are interested in the potential development of Nitrogen Emission Control Areas (NECAs) in European waters - or inclusion of marine pollution within NECD limits - specifically for NOx
